p: Fomitopsis pinicola (Sw. Karst), is a common woody fungus found in coniferous forests in temperate regions throughout Europe and Asia [ 1], including the Himalayas [ 2]. Numerous local names exist for F. pinicola, such as the Japanese name, which is Tsugasaruno-koshikake [ 3], and the English name of red-belted bracket fungus [ 4]. Fomitopsis pinicola is commonly known as a brown-rot fungus, characterised by bipolar sexual compatibility and the presence of the phenol oxidase, tyrosinase (with extracellular oxidase not present) [ 3]. It has been used in Chinese and Korean traditional folk medicine as an anti-inflammatory agent and for general well-being.
